awd_titl_txt: Developing Abilities and Knowledge for Careers in Design and Engineering for Students on the Autism Spectrum by Scaling Up Making Experiences
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a proposal submitted to the Successful Project Expansion and Dissemination strand of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program. People on the autism spectrum are very capable of leading productive lives and have interests and abilities that can enable them to make valuable contributions to their communities. For example, research shows that young people with autism who go to college choose science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) majors at higher rates than college students in the general population. With one out of every 59 people in the United States on the autism spectrum, it is essential to create programs that prepare this segment of the population for full participation in the workforce so our society can benefit from the unique perspectives they have to offer. This project scales up an Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) project called IDEAS: Inventing, Designing, and Engineering on the Autism Spectrum, in which a multidisciplinary team adapted a museum-based maker program and tested it in three autism inclusion middle schools in New York City. The project will build on the lessons learned from that project to bring maker programming to a wider range of students, teachers, and schools, and to increase the education community's understanding about how maker programming can help young people on the autism spectrum gain the social, functional, and communication skills necessary for careers in design and engineering. 

The goals of the project are (1) to expand the program to more autism inclusion middle schools, (2) to expand the program to autism inclusion elementary and high schools, (3) to make the program sustainable by facilitating local adaptation in autism inclusion schools, (4) to shift the ownership of the program to autism inclusion schools and the city's professional development providers and special education office, and (5) to explore more broadly how making can support autism inclusion efforts in general. To achieve these goals, we will establish a collaborative co-design process that will include current partners (Education Development Center, New York University's Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) Nest Support Project, New York Hall of Science), as well as autism inclusion schools (teachers and principals) and an advisor from the New York City Department of Education's Special Education Office. By the end of this three-year project, there will be 12 Maker Programs run by 24 teachers, reaching approximately 150,180 students on and off the spectrum each year. The team also will explore what it will take to sustain such a program and to build the capacity of the ASD Nest Support Project to have engineering design maker programming available beyond the life of this grant to the other districts to which their autism inclusion model is expanding. These activities will build knowledge in the larger special education and informal education communities about how making can enhance autism inclusion efforts and eventually increase the participation of young people on the autism spectrum in STEM careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
This scale-up project extended a design and development ITEST project called IDEAS: Inventing, designing and engineering on the autism spectrum (award # 1614436). That project brought together researchers from Education Development Center (EDC) and SRI, engineering design/maker program experts from New York Hall of Science (NYSCI), autism support experts from New York University (NYU), and educators and students in the New York City Public Schools (NYCPS). IDEAS developed an engineering design maker program to be implemented in NYCPS autism inclusion middle schools by educators from those schools. This project brought the same team together to 

 

  • reach more NYCPS schools, including elementary and high schools

  • make the program sustainable in NYCPS

  • transfer ownership to NYCPS

  • explore how maker programs can support autistic learners more broadly

 

Because our goal was to create a program that could last beyond the end of the grant period, we worked closely with NYCPS educators and administrators to make sure we co-designed programs, materials, and professional development (PD) that were adapted to their context and met their needs. Together we co-created the following:

  • a remote version of the program and PD during the pandemic 

  • a second World Building curriculum for younger students that was more focused on crafts than the original program, which focused on 3D design and 3D printing, 

  • slide decks aligned with the two curricula for educators to use during the program

  • a guide for implementing the program during a four-week summer camp that NYCPS runs for autistic students every year

 

To transfer ownership, we also trained NYCPS coaches to be PD providers for the program and have provided maker program kits and co-designed PD slide decks for them to use in future PDs. To ensure sustainability in NYCPS as well as other school districts and informal organizations, we created an accessible website with the curricula, slide decks, videos of teacher tips and other resources that educators need to run the program, and have run workshops at multiple venues and conferences described in the broader impact section below.

In addition, our experience implementing the program in high schools led us to create a pilot mentorship program that connected autistic college students with autistic high school students to engage in interest-based science, technology, engineering, arts and math (STEAM) projects. This small pilot led to the development of a new ITEST-funded project called Making Mentors: Enhancing Access to STEM Careers for Autistic Youth through Mentorship Programs in Makerspaces (Award # 2241350), a collaboration among EDC, NYU and the College of Staten Island.

 

Intellectual Merit

This project built on the research indicating that interest-based programming can support the development of workforce skills and academic knowledge for many young people, and particularly autistic youth. While our research was impacted by pandemic-related limitations on school access, the research we were able to complete demonstrated promising results. During the year that schools were fully remote, we worked with educators to co-design a remote version of the IDEAS Maker Program and PD. Six schools implemented the remote program. Surveys of teachers demonstrated that the vast majority felt prepared to implement the remote program, agreed that students were able to make social connections and improved their engineering design process (EDP) skills. In the following year, IDEAS Maker Program was implemented in person but research needed to be done remotely. Research data collected that year indicated that while the program did not change participants’ interest in STEM, it did increase their understanding of components of the EDP, specifically planning, testing and improving. Qualitative research based on student and educator interviews and observations conducted once researchers were allowed in schools has also demonstrated that the program has helped participants build problem solving skills, learn how to cope with frustration and gain a sense of agency and self-determination. This project produced eleven peer-reviewed publications (plus one under revision and another submitted), 34 conference presentations (plus two more accepted and one more submitted), one PhD dissertation and another nearing completion.

 

Broader Impact

We have disseminated broadly about this project to many audiences. 

  • Six presentations to NYC Public School educators, reaching over 300 people 

  • One NSF STEM4All video (which received a Facilitator’s Choice award)

  • Participation in an NSF STEM4All multiplex event on Neurodiversity in STEM

  • IDEAS Maker Program PD to ~ 100 NYC Public Schools educators (teachers and occupational therapists)

  • IDEAS Maker Program PD to a cohort of six NYCPS coaches who have provided PD to ~ 75 NYC educators, and have four more PDs planned for late summer and fall 2024 for ~ 80 more 

  • IDEAS Maker Program PD for ~ 250 informal educators at Exploratorium in San Francisco, Autistry Studios in San Rafael, CA, and Kid Museum in Bethesda, MD and workshops presented at the Association of Science and Technology Centers (ASTC) and American Alliance of Museums (AAM) conferences and Bibliotheca, an international community of librarians
